author: HCAndersen
text: ONCE upon a time lived a poor prince; his kingdom was very small, but it was large enough to enable him to marry, and marry he would.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was rather bold of him that he went and asked the emperor's daughter: "Will you marry me?" but he ventured to do so, for his name was known far and wide, and there were hundreds of princesses who would have gladly accepted him, but would she do so?

author: HCAndersen
text: Now we shall see.

author: HCAndersen
text: On the grave of the prince's father grew a rose-tree, the most beautiful of its kind.

author: HCAndersen
text: It bloomed only once in five years, and then it had only one single rose upon it, but what a rose!

author: HCAndersen
text: It had such a sweet scent that one instantly forgot all sorrow and grief when one smelt it.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had also a nightingale, which could sing as if every sweet melody was in its throat.

author: HCAndersen
text: This rose and the nightingale he wished to give to the princess; and therefore both were put into big silver cases and sent to her.

author: HCAndersen
text: The emperor ordered them to be carried into the great hall where the princess was just playing "Visitors are coming" with her ladies-in-waiting; when she saw the large cases with the presents therein, she clapped her hands for joy.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wish it were a little pussy cat," she said.

author: HCAndersen
text: But then the rose-tree with the beautiful rose was unpacked.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, how nicely it is made," exclaimed the ladies.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is more than nice," said the emperor, "it is charming."

author: HCAndersen
text: The princess touched it and nearly began to cry.

author: HCAndersen
text: "For shame, pa," she said, "it is not artificial, it is natural!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "For shame, it is natural" repeated all her ladies.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Let us first see what the other case contains before we are angry," said the emperor; then the nightingale was taken out, and it sang so beautifully that no one could possibly say anything unkind about it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Superbe, charmant," said the ladies of the court, for they all prattled French, one worse than the other.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How much the bird reminds me of the musical box of the late lamented empress," said an old courtier, "it has exactly the same tone, the same execution."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You are right," said the emperor, and began to cry like a little child.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I hope it is not natural," said the princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, certainly it is natural," replied those who had brought the presents.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Then let it fly," said the princess, and refused to see the prince.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the prince was not discouraged.

author: HCAndersen
text: He painted his face, put on common clothes, pulled his cap over his forehead, and came back.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Good day, emperor," he said, "could you not give me some employment at the court?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "There are so many," replied the emperor, "who apply for places, that for the present I have no vacancy, but I will remember you.

author: HCAndersen
text: But wait a moment; it just comes into my mind, I require somebody to look after my pigs, for I have a great many."

author: HCAndersen
text: Thus the prince was appointed imperial swineherd, and as such he lived in a wretchedly small room near the pigsty; there he worked all day long, and when it was night he had made a pretty little pot.

author: HCAndersen
text: There were little bells round the rim, and when the water began to boil in it, the bells began to play the old tune:

author: HCAndersen
text: "A jolly old sow once lived in a sty, Three little piggies had she," &c.

author: HCAndersen
text: But what was more wonderful was that, when one put a finger into the steam rising from the pot, one could at once smell what meals they were preparing on every fire in the whole town.

author: HCAndersen
text: That was indeed much more remarkable than the rose.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the princess with her ladies passed by and heard the tune, she stopped and looked quite pleased, for she also could play it- in fact, it was the only tune she could play, and she played it with one finger.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is the tune I know," she exclaimed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "He must be a well-educated swineherd.

author: HCAndersen
text: Go and ask him how much the instrument is."

author: HCAndersen
text: One of the ladies had to go and ask; but she put on pattens.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What will you take for your pot?" asked the lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I will have ten kisses from the princess," said the swineherd.

author: HCAndersen
text: "God forbid," said the lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, I cannot sell it for less," replied the swineherd.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What did he say?" said the princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: I really cannot tell you," replied the lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You can whisper it into my ear."

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is very naughty," said the princess, and walked off.

author: HCAndersen
text: But when she had gone a little distance, the bells rang again so sweetly:

author: HCAndersen
text: "A jolly old sow once lived in a sty, Three little piggies had she," &c.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ask him," said the princess, "if he will be satisfied with ten kisses from one of my ladies."

author: HCAndersen
text: "No, thank you," said the swineherd: "ten kisses from the princess, or I keep my pot."

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is tiresome," said the princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But you must stand before me, so that nobody can see it."

author: HCAndersen
text: The ladies placed themselves in front of her and spread out their dresses, and she gave the swineherd ten kisses and received the pot.

author: HCAndersen
text: That was a pleasure!

author: HCAndersen
text: Day and night the water in the pot was boiling; there was not a single fire in the whole town of which they did not know what was preparing on it, the chamberlain's as well as the shoemaker's.

author: HCAndersen
text: The ladies danced and clapped their hands for joy.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We know who will eat soup and pancakes; we know who will eat porridge and cutlets; oh, how interesting!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Very interesting, indeed," said the mistress of the household.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But you must not betray me, for I am the emperor's daughter."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Of course not," they all said.

author: HCAndersen
text: The swineherd- that is to say, the prince- but they did not know otherwise than that he was a real swineherd- did not waste a single day without doing something; he made a rattle, which, when turned quickly round, played all the waltzes, galops, and polkas known since the creation of the world.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But that is superbe," said the princess passing by.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have never heard a more beautiful composition.

author: HCAndersen
text: Go down and ask him what the instrument costs; but I shall not kiss him again."

author: HCAndersen
text: "He will have a hundred kisses from the princess," said the lady, who had gone down to ask him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I believe he is mad," said the princess, and walked off, but soon she stopped.

author: HCAndersen
text: "One must encourage art," she said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am the emperor's daughter!

author: HCAndersen
text: Tell him I will give him ten kisses, as I did the other day; the remainder one of my ladies can give him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But we do not like to kiss him" said the ladies.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is nonsense," said the princess; "if I can kiss him, you can also do it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Remember that I give you food and employment."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the lady had to go down once more.

author: HCAndersen
text: "A hundred kisses from the princess," said the swineherd, "or everybody keeps his own."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Place yourselves before me," said the princess then.

author: HCAndersen
text: They did as they were bidden, and the princess kissed him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wonder what that crowd near the pigsty means!" said the emperor, who had just come out on his balcony.

author: HCAndersen
text: He rubbed his eyes and put his spectacles on.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The ladies of the court are up to some mischief, I think.

author: HCAndersen
text: I shall have to go down and see."

author: HCAndersen
text: He pulled up his shoes, for they were down at the heels, and he was very quick about it.

author: HCAndersen
text: When he had come down into the courtyard he walked quite softly, and the ladies were so busily engaged in counting the kisses, that all should be fair, that they did not notice the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
text: He raised himself on tiptoe.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What does this mean?" he said, when he saw that his daughter was kissing the swineherd, and then hit their heads with his shoe just as the swineherd received the sixty-eighth kiss.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Go out of my sight," said the emperor, for he was very angry; and both the princess and the swineherd were banished from the empire.

author: HCAndersen
text: There she stood and cried, the swineherd scolded her, and the rain came down in torrents.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Alas, unfortunate creature that I am!" said the princess, "I wish I had accepted the prince.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, how wretched I am!"

author: HCAndersen
text: The swineherd went behind a tree, wiped his face, threw off his poor attire and stepped forth in his princely garments; he looked so beautiful that the princess could not help bowing to him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have now learnt to despise you," he said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You refused an honest prince; you did not appreciate the rose and the nightingale; but you did not mind kissing a swineherd for his toys; you have no one but yourself to blame!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And then he returned into his kingdom and left her behind.

author: HCAndersen
text: She could now sing at her leisure:

author: HCAndersen
text: "A jolly old sow once lived in a sty, Three little piggies has she," &c.
